At first glance, I'd say the probability is close to 0. While Zuckerberg may be pressured to relinquish some power, it is unlikely this will happen before August 1st; however, I looked at the different scenarios that could lead to a "Yes":
- Zuckerberg steps down as Chairman: <1% - a situation in which Zuckerberg chooses to report (as CEO) to the board headed by someone else seems very unlikely; if he would step down due to poor PR or legal scrutiny, stepping down as CEO would have a greater PR impact. Very unlikely before August 1st
- Zuckerberg steps down as CEO: ~1% - Moving to just the chairman role would allow Zuckerberg to maintain significant power over Facebook while losing some direct control. Very unlikely before August 1st
- Zuckerberg announces a leave of absence: ~2% - Generally more likely than directly stepping down, it would still be very unlikely to happen before August 1st
- Addition of a Co-CEO: <1% - Investors and board members (and Zuckerberg himself, as Chairman) would be aware that co-CEOs generally don't work out unless there is significant alignment and trust between the co-CEOs (and not often, even then)
- Addition of a Co-Chair: <1% - Similar to the argument for stepping down as chairman. This would be relinquishing significant power for limited gain.

I think it is likely that Mark Zuckerberg will stay. The big assumption underlying my prediction is this: Mark Zuckerberg currently lacks a successor. The man supposed to succeed Mark was Chris Cox (see Technadu article). However, he left Facebook. Since Chris left, Mark organized many of the leaders of Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and WhatsApp. In Mark’s words: “Since we [Facebook] have now decided on the basic direction of our family of apps for the next few years, I do not plan on immediately appointing anyone to fill Chris’s role in the near term. Instead, the leaders of Facebook (Fidji Simo), Instagram (Adam Mosseri), Messenger (Stan Chudnovsky), and WhatsApp (Will Cathcart) will report directly to me, and our Chief Marketing Officer (Antonio Lucio) will report directly to Sheryl.” (A Note From Mark Zuckerberg). Essentially, if Mark Zuckerberg ceases to be CEO, who will run Facebook? I think he may stay because the consequences of walking away seem too great, especially for the potential power of Facebook. He built the company, and seems to have plans to move it forward regardless of criticisms. Still, I could be wrong. If Mark finds a successor soon or already has one we don’t know about, then this prediction becomes defunct. Also, forecasting Mark’s actions is difficult. He may decide that the stress is too unbearable, or that Facebook may do better without his presence. It is difficult to tell. The big question: How does Mark Zuckerberg understand the situation? Sources: https://newsroom.fb.com/news/2019/03/a-note-from-mark-zuckerberg/

https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1326801/000132680119000025/facebook2019definitiveprox.htm#s01F926C417505621961CDE3214E4713A ROPOSAL SIX:
STOCKHOLDER PROPOSAL REGARDING AN INDEPENDENT CHAIR
Independent Board Chairperson
Resolved: Shareholders request the Board of Directors adopt as policy, and amend the bylaws as necessary, to require henceforth that the Chair of the Board of Directors, whenever possible, be an independent member of the Board. This independence policy shall apply prospectively so as not to violate any contractual obligations. If the Board determines that a Chair who was independent when selected is no longer independent, the Board shall select a new Chair who satisfies the requirements of the policy within a reasonable amount of time. Compliance with this policy is waived if no independent director is available and willing to serve as Chair.
Supporting Statement:
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has been Board Chair since 2012. His dual-class shareholdings give him approximately 60% of Facebook's voting shares, leaving the board, even with a lead independent director, with only a limited ability to check Mr. Zuckerberg's power. We believe this weakens Facebook's governance and oversight of management. Selecting an independent Chair would free the CEO to focus on managing the Company and enable the Chairperson to focus on oversight and strategic guidance.
The Council of Institutional Investors argues:
Having an independent chair helps the board carry out its primary duty — to monitor the management of the company on behalf of its shareowners. A CEO who also serves as chair can exert excessive influence on the board and its agenda, weakening the board's oversight of management. Separating the chair and CEO positions reduces this conflict, and an independent chair provides the clearest separation of power between the CEO and the rest of the board.
Facebook has resisted recent shareholder requests to separate these roles. In 2017, according to our calculations, a similar proposal received the support of 51% of the votes cast when excluding the shares of 13 executives and board members. However, the board has not acted on this important signal from its non-insider shareholders.
Google, Microsoft, Apple, Oracle, and Twitter have separate CEO and chairperson roles. More broadly, 59% of the S&P 1500 separated these roles as of April 2018.
We believe this lack of independent board Chair and oversight has contributed to Facebook missing, or mishandling, a number of severe controversies, increasing risk exposure and costs to shareholders. Examples from past years include:
•
Russian meddling in U.S. elections
•
Sharing personal data of 87 million users with Cambridge Analytica
•
Data sharing with device manufacturers, including Huawei that is flagged by U.S. Intelligence as a national security threat
•
Proliferating fake news
•
Propagating violence in Myanmar, India, and South Sudan
•
Depression and other mental health issues, including stress and addiction
•
Allowing advertisers to exclude black, Hispanic, and other "ethnic affinities" from seeing ads. In apologies, Mr. Zuckerberg has stated, "We didn't take a broad enough view of our responsibility." This broader view is what an independent Board Chair would provide, which we believe would benefit the company, its shareholders, and its global community of users.

Over the next 25 years, 87% of voters believe Facebook will have to deal with significant competition that will challenge its dominance. A ScottRasmussen.com poll found that 52% believe it is likely that the social media giant will actually go out of business during that time. Voters also overwhelmingly believe that Google, Amazon, and Apple will face significant competition over the coming quarter of a century. However, most believe those companies will survive. Just 26% believe Apple will go out of business, 23% say the same about Google, and 20% think Amazon will disappear. Other survey data shows that 55% of voters believe Facebook has too much power today. However, just 21% believe the federal government should impose regulations on social media companies to ensure equal opportunities for all points of view. The reluctance to embrace a political solution may stem partly from the belief that companies like Facebook will face significant competition. Additionally, many perceive that political solutions to achieve admirable goals often do more harm than good. For example, 64% of voters believe letting the government define hate speech is more dangerous than hate speech itself.

There is 36.4% of a year left, so the base rate of 10.2%/year goes to 3.71% For similar logic, I'm willing to round to 0.0% on all scenarios except "Zuckerberg resigns - 59% of CEOs that transition each year resign." Thus, 1.1%

To tackle this question, I first asked myself "How long is the average CEO tenure?" The average tenure is 7.2 years and the median is 5.0 years. Next, I asked first myself "How could a CEO and/or Chairman transition from his/her role at a company?" A little research indicated the following scenarios:
1) A majority vote by shareholders or the board (depending on company bylaws) to remove CEO and/or Chairman - This rarely happens for large companies. Only 10 CEOs of S&P 500 companies have been terminated since 2008.
2) Chairman reaches the term limit for Board members.
3) Chairman and/or CEO chooses to retire or resign - An average 50 of CEOs at S&P 500 companies have retired or resigned each year.
4) Chairman and/or CEO agrees to share responsibilities.
5) Chairman and/or CEO announces leave of absence - These are rare because boards do not like CEOs to take leaves of absence.
6) Company ceases to exist. Starting Point: An average of 51 CEOs of S&P 500 companies transition each year. This turnover rate (10.2%) was my starting point. Zuckerberg has been CEO since the company was founded in 2004 (15 years), so he is in the 12th-percentile for longest tenured CEOs in the S&P500. Finally, I asked myself "How could Mark Zuckerberg be removed from his position as Chairman and/or CEO?"
1) Shareholders vote to remove him as CEO and/or Chairman - 0% probability because Zuckerberg owns a majority voting share (~53.3%) of the company. This lowers probability to 10%.
2) Zuckerberg reaches term limit as board member - 0% probability because, to my knowledge, there is no such term for Facebook. This does not change the probability.
3) Zuckerberg retires - 41% of CEOs that transition each year retire. Mark has been portrayed as a self-motivated individual that seeks new ventures. At the age of 34, it is unlikely, but possible, that he might retire. Therefore, I think this reduces the probability from 10% to 9%.
4) Zuckerberg resigns - 59% of CEOs that transition each year resign. I think this is the most likely scenario in which Zuckerberg transitions. Zuckerberg is known for his love of travel and trying new things. The mounting pressure due to recent scandals over user privacy could offer an opportunity for him to get out. I give this a 10% chance, which reduces the probability from 9% to 3%.
6) Zuckerberg announces a co-Chairman/CEO or takes leave of absence- Zuckerberg has consistently shown that he wants sole ownership of Facebook. In addition, it is very rare for a CEO/Chairman to take leave of absence. 0% change in probability.
7) Facebook ceases to exist - 0% chance before August 1st.

Thought process below, not totally in logical order: 1) Zuckerberg himself as recently as November 2018 said that he didn't think it was a good idea to step down as Chairman.
2) In the ten years from 2004 to 2014, the % of S&P 500 companies with joint Chairman/CEOs reduced from 75% to c.55% (two sources: one said just under 60%, the other 50%). That equates to 10 companies (net) a year moving away from this structure. We have 7 months to August, so you'd expect c.6 in that time. That is 1.2% of the S&P 500. This feels like a sensible base rate. I don't know why those companies or what type of companies enacted these changes though.
3) Facebook is a controlled company. c.120 of the S&P 1500 (8%) are like this. I'd conclude that the chances are virtually zero that this would happen unless Zuckerberg wanted it to or felt obliged due to outside forces. I have not found any examples of shareholders successfully proposing a change to a controlled company.
4) Proposals are made annually to change the shareholder structure to reduce Zuckerberg's voting power indicating some unrest/pressure. From 2014 to 2017 these proposals have received between 17% & 20% of all votes. One AGM occurs between now and the end of this question (end of May). 
5) We are then reliant purely on government or extreme external pressure to force a change (or Zuckerberg changing his own mind i.e. wanting to retire) 
5) I would say it is vastly more likely that the majority of the 10 annual changes of this nature occur in non-controlled companies. That would mean that the probability is potentially closer to 0% than 1% (can't do to 1dp here). I don't want to put zero as that suggests literally no chance.
6) A catalyst for change would need to be seismic. The scandals the company suffered in 2017 were pretty seismic and yet no change has been forthcoming. 
7) I am not aware of any immediate deadlines for impending investigations into the company specifically that are likely to result in government intervention (incl. anti-trust) before this question ends. There could be more revelations re: Russia but my sense is everyone already assumes FB is guilty of everything under the sun - I am not sure sentiment could get worse (perhaps naively).
8) I did find one instance of Zuckerberg not getting his way as regards corporate governance. In September 2017 he wanted to reclassify share classes to allow him to sell more shares to fund charity work without ceding any power. Zuckerberg backed down after a lawsuit was threatened. However, Zuckerberg also said that the performance of the share price meant that this reclassification was no longer necessary and he was able to make the donations he wanted to for the next 20 years without impacting on his control of the business (or level of donations). The share price in September 2017 was c.$170, 13% higher than today's $150 (27 January 2019) so not materially different. In conclusion, I would forecast the probability at 1%, below the base rate I established due to its controlled status. I could not find anything that suggests I should move this up materially other than the fact that it is established as a question in the media. The timeframe is also very short for this question and so the likelihood of the sort of catalyst required to enact the change is very low in my view.
